entry.title: Featured
entry.summary: Featured Organization - Mercy Washington, Washington, MO Scenario-based simulation has been found to be an effective learning strategy to enhance the safe delivery of patient interventions and professional competencies in high-risk, low-incidence clinical situations. The realistic design of simulation enables the learner to transfer what…
entry.content:
Featured Organization - Mercy Washington, Washington, MO

 Scenario-based simulation has been found to be an effective learning strategy to enhance the safe delivery of patient interventions and professional competencies in high-risk, low-incidence clinical situations. The realistic design of simulation enables the learner to transfer what they have learned in the simulated setting to the clinical setting in comparison to other methods of education, for example online course modules or didactic lecture (Merchant, 2012). Scenario-based simulation is often only provided in larger hospital facilities or academic settings. However, this type of learning is invaluable for the smaller community or rural hospitals as well.

 Mercy Hospital Washington is an acute care hospital offering comprehensive critical care, medical, surgical, obstetric, and pediatric services. Mercy Hospital Washington began utilizing scenario-based simulation for multidisciplinary training and education several years ago. More recently, the hospital developed a complete simulation training lab, which although small, effectively simulates a patient room and provide realistic training for its co-workers. The training includes scenarios such as detecting a patient experiencing a stroke, taking the patient to CT, using the hospital’s Telestroke technology cart, and actually delivering TPA to the patient. Facilitators also run the simulation manikin remotely, to avoid interfering with co-workers participating in the scenario. The simulation lab is used extensively in Mercy Hospital Washington’s Nursing Fellowship and PCA Fellowship programs.

 Mercy’s use of simulation is not restricted to its simulation lab. The hospital also provides scenario-based education through the use of mock codes. It is also expanding its out-of-the-lab training to include simulated experiences in the labor and delivery department and training of the hospital’s rapid response team.

 Simulation should not be restricted to large facilities or academic settings, but should be available in all clinical settings large and small. A quote from the aviation industry is a fantastic example of why simulation is so valuable:

“Pilots don’t spend their training time flying straight and level. In simulator training, we’re doing nothing but flying in all sorts of emergencies. Even emergencies become just another set of procedures when repeatedly trained”

- Spencer, 2008

 The statement is true for all clinical environments.

entry.title: Resources
entry.summary: Simulation Resources Free resources:Sim-one http://www.sim-one.ca/scenarioUniversity of South Dakota http://www.usd.edu/health-sciences/nursing/simulation-scenariosUniversity of Washington http://collaborate.uw.edu/tools-and-curricula/scenario-building-and-library.htmlMontgomery College https://cms.montgomerycollege.edu/nursingsims/#top2Kansas Board of Nursing http://www.ksbn.org/education/Scenario/SimulationScenarioLibrary.htmQSEN Institute http://qsen.org/teaching-strategies/strategy-search/advanced-search-results/?strat_type=Simulation%20Exercises Paid resources:http://www.mysimcenter.com/en-US/SimStoreHome.aspx
entry.content:
Simulation Resources

 

NLN SIRC (National League for Nursing Simulation Innovation Resource Center:
http://sirc.nln.org/ -- Collaboration between Laerdal and NLN. Offers online courses and discussion forums as well as research instruments
 
SSH (Society for Simulation in Healthcare):
http://www.ssih.org/ -- multidisciplinary society, holds annual conference. Provides Lab accreditation as well as individual certification (CHSE, etc.). Offers webinars, prep courses, and a journal. Online SimCenter directory available.
 
INACSL (International Nursing Association for Clinical Simulation & Learning):
http://www.inacsl.org/ -- Promotes research, created evidence based practice standards for simulation. Hosts annual conference for nursing simulation. Journal, webinars, and research grants, as well as mentorships.
 
Simghosts (The Gathering of Healthcare Simulation Technology Specialists):
http://www.simghosts.org/sim/default.asp -- Non-profit organization dedicated to supporting the growing international population of professionals operating medical simulation technology and spaces.
 
Laerdal SUN (Simulation User Network):
https://www.laerdal.com/us/learn/sun -- A network of peers and experts in the realm of simulation, hosted by Laerdal. There are semi-annual conferences for simulation pedagogy and technology.
http://simulation.laerdal.com/forum/files/default.aspx
 
University of Washington:
http://collaborate.uw.edu/resources-and-publications/simulation-resources.html 
http://healthysimulation.com/
https://harvardmedsim.org/
 

Tools and Resources

 

DASH Tool: http://collaborate.uw.edu/sites/default/files/files/IMSH_2009_DASH.pdf
The Debriefing Assessment for Simulation in Healthcare is designed to assist in evaluating and developing debriefing skills.
 
InCITE Clinical Debriefing Tool:
http://collaborate.uw.edu/educators-toolkit/debriefing-tools/incite-debriefing-tool.html
Modeled on Debriefing with Good Judgment
 
WISER resources:
http://www.wiser.pitt.edu/
Offers online classes and training for sim specialists and more
 
CAE’s Simulation Effectiveness Tool:
http://caehealthcare.com//images/uploads/documents/Simulation_Effectiveness_Tool_0812.pdf
 

Scenario Resources

 

Free resources:
Sim-one http://www.sim-one.ca/scenario
University of South Dakota http://www.usd.edu/health-sciences/nursing/simulation-scenarios
University of Washington http://collaborate.uw.edu/tools-and-curricula/scenario-building-and-library.html
Montgomery College https://cms.montgomerycollege.edu/nursingsims/#top2
Kansas Board of Nursing http://www.ksbn.org/education/Scenario/SimulationScenarioLibrary.htm
QSEN Institute http://qsen.org/teaching-strategies/strategy-search/advanced-search-results/?strat_type=Simulation%20Exercises
 
Paid resources:
http://www.mysimcenter.com/en-US/SimStoreHome.aspx

entry.title: About
entry.summary: The Saint Louis Simulation Group (SLSIG) was spearheaded by several simulation experts in the St. Louis region who wanted to bring the simulation community together for collaboration, education and resources. Support excellence in simulation facilitation through collaboration and sharing of best practices. The SLSIG will…
entry.content:
The Saint Louis Simulation Group (SLSIG) was spearheaded by several simulation experts in the St. Louis region who wanted to bring the simulation community together for collaboration, education and resources.

Our Mission

Support excellence in simulation facilitation through collaboration and sharing of best practices.

Our Vision

The SLSIG will foster collaboration, use of best practices through research, patient safety, and professional development among simulation facilitators in both clinical practice and education.

entry.title: The St. Louis Simulation Interest Group
entry.summary: Created to bring together the healthcare simulation community in St. Louis and the surrounding region, the St. Louis Simulation Interest Group is open to all those who provide simulation education in any healthcare setting. Review and approve Meeting MinutesReview open offices. Vote for candidatesIV trainer…
entry.content:
Created to bring together the healthcare simulation community in St. Louis and the surrounding region, the St. Louis Simulation Interest Group is open to all those who provide simulation education in any healthcare setting.

Upcoming Events

November Meeting
Nov 11, 2019: 1:30pm - 3:30pm
St. Luke's Meeting Room
(East Medical Office Building Lower Level room 80)

  • Review and approve Meeting Minutes
  • Review open offices. Vote for candidates
  • IV trainer demonstration
  • Website updates
  • Peter Weinstock ted talk
  • 2020 Goals:  
  1. Creating the New Website
  2. Sharing simulation and how it is integrated into curriculum
  3. Formalize monthly practice sharing
  4. Do we need office job descriptions?
  5. Do we need a mission?
